title: Acoustic Monitoring of Avian Biodiversity at Gaulossen Nature Reserve
subtitle: A Comprehensive Analysis of 48.8 Hours of Continuous Recording

abstract.background: Passive acoustic monitoring provides non-invasive, continuous assessment of avian communities. We deployed autonomous recording units at Gaulossen Nature Reserve to document species composition and behavioral patterns.
abstract.methods: 48.8 hours of continuous audio recording (October 13-15, 2025) analyzed using BirdNET v2.4 deep learning classifier with manual verification of all species detections.
abstract.results: Detected 90 species with 82 verified (91.1% verification rate). Dominant species: Graylag Goose (2,871 calls), Spotted Crake (2,556 calls). Documented 756 nocturnal flight calls, 150 interspecies call-response pairs, and 5 multi-species alarm cascades.
abstract.conclusions: Gaulossen supports remarkably diverse wetland avifauna including rare species (Great Snipe leks). High social coordination evident through call-response networks and alarm cascades. Active nocturnal migration corridor documented.

introduction.study_site: Gaulossen Nature Reserve (63.4305°N, 10.3951°E), Stjørdal, Norway. Freshwater wetland complex with emergent vegetation, open water, and surrounding agricultural land.
objectives: Document avian species richness and abundance during autumn migration
Quantify behavioral patterns including flight calls, social interactions, and temporal activity
Validate automated species identification through manual verification
Assess effectiveness of passive acoustic monitoring for wetland bird surveys
hypotheses: Wetland species will dominate detections due to habitat type
Nocturnal migration activity will be detectable through flight calls
Social species will show coordinated calling patterns and alarm responses

methods.equipment: Autonomous recording units (unspecified model), 48 kHz sampling rate, 16-bit depth
methods.deployment: October 13-15, 2025. Single recorder location, continuous 48.8-hour recording
methods.weather: Predominantly rain and fog (80%+ of recording period)

analysis_pipeline.detection: BirdNET v2.4 (Kahl et al. 2021) with 0.25 confidence threshold, Norwegian species filter (270 species)
analysis_pipeline.verification: Manual review of spectrograms and audio for all 90 detected species

behavioral_analysis.flight_calls: Classified by context (nocturnal, landing, pre-flight, in-flight contact)

key_findings: Extremely high wetland species dominance (86.6%) reflects specialized habitat
Graylag Goose flock behavior at extreme end (98.7% flock calling)
Great Snipe lek timing (20:00-21:00 peak) matches Norwegian studies
Sentinel mutualism between crows and geese (8,778 co-occurrences)
Active migration corridor with clear nocturnal flight patterns
conservation_implications: Great Snipe lek documentation important for declining species
High species richness indicates healthy wetland ecosystem
Nocturnal migration suggests importance as stopover site
Rare species detections (21) require follow-up confirmation
methodological_insights: Rain noise major challenge (129 false Great Bittern detections)
91.1% verification rate validates BirdNET for wetland monitoring
Manual review essential for rare/low-confidence species
Behavioral analysis adds significant value beyond species lists

technical: Some rare species detections require field confirmation

future_directions: Year-round monitoring for full seasonal patterns
Integration with visual surveys for validation
Weather-gated recording to reduce rain noise
Advanced noise filtering for wet-weather conditions
acknowledgments: BirdNET (Cornell Lab), Raven Pro (Cornell Lab), Norwegian species databases
data_availability: Raw data, spectrograms, and analysis code available at https://github.com/Ziforge/gaulossen-study
